column1:
Firox_5000,"2014-01-24T15:25:22.827Z","Battle in Utapau","This is the first Star Wars set and I bought during 2014 which despite looking the least exciting of a wave full of battle packs, I was quite surprised how this set turned out.

Box, Packaging and building experience
column2: The set comes in a small rectangular box, which is the usual size of all battle packs, with the exception of the 2013 ones which were a small square size. There are two non numbered bags and one instruction manual.
column3:
The build takes around 15 minutes, which is a quick build, with a couple of fiddly moments with the placing of the lower cape on the figures. There's a few repetitive moments with the placement of the robot structure's legs.

The set and figures
There are four figures included in this set, two 212th battalion troopers and two airborne troopers.

The Battalion troopers feature
column4: a clone head similar to those of last year with orange printing at the top and additional black printings at the lower part of the helmet and other small printings at the sides. The troopers include a sweaty and determined facial expression beneath the helmet which is identical on all four figures.&nbsp
column5: The torso features yellow printing on the top and sides of the chest and a belt below and at the back numerous other printings. The figure also features also coloured arms and additional orange printing on the legs of the figure, making a nice blend of white and orange on both.
column6: The Airborne troopers feature a slightly larger and beefy helmet piece with breathing equipment running up to the centre of the helmet and a long as well as orange and grey printings at the sides of the bottom of the helmet.
column7:
The torso features printing of a strap, a orange and yellow belt and black printing at the top let side. There's also one orange and white coloured arm too. The back features another printed strap and white equipment . The legs feature grey and black printing on one leg and orange and black on the other. There's also the lower cape piece too, giving them a more prepared in combat appearance.

Whilst the figure are pretty good with nice new details, this years battle packs see the addition of a brand new type of blaster guns that can fire small circle bricks out from a small switch at the top which is pushed.
column8: Despite being one step back in terms of appearances, the new blaster guns are brilliant and are great fun to use, which can be shot out easily and can go a surprisingly amount of distance and add a great amount of playability to the set.
column9:
Apart from the figures and new boasters, the only other element of the set is a Tri droid structure which features three identical legs which adjusted by the joints for different poses. The top centre piece features three flick missiles which although add to the playability of the set remain as usual rather stiff and difficult to fire. The top area can also rotate around to add more to playability further which can be actually spun if lifted off the ground.

Conclusion
column11: very good battle pack set with some great new figures, impressive new boasters and a fairly good Tri droid. Whilst not quite as good as the Kashyk troopers, it poses as a great little set and an improvement from the mostly disappointing battle packs produced in 2012 and 2013.&nbsp
column12:
Would recommend this battle pack to all Star Wars fans and army builders.
",TRUE,5,5,3,5,4

column2: ve been waiting a long time for this set to come out in the U.S., and it finally came out in February. After purchasing the CAC&nbsp
column3: Ep3&nbsp
column4: Commander Cody, I wanted to be able to build him an army. Thus battle pack worked out perfectly. I received 3 of these for my B-day
column5: my mom got them for BOGO&nbsp
column6: 50% off. It was originally retailing for 15 dollars each at Toys R Us.&nbsp

column1: Both the box and instructions are both what you would expect: small. The box artwork does not have a very effective setup, with ineffective placement of the minifigures. The box also features a spot where one would press their finger to open (and unfortunately destroy) the box.
Besides the troopers themselves, the parts include many click hinge beams which can occasionally be useful. The pieces also include a 4x4 dark tan dome, which, forgive me if I'
column2: m wrong, is unique to the set. It also includes 4 of the new doing blasters, which are great for kids, but I had&nbsp
column3: to order some DC-15 blasters and blaster riffles from CAC&nbsp
column4: and Brickarms.

column1: The minifigures, which are the highlight of the set, are probably the most detailed clone troopers Lego has ever produced along with the Kashyyyk troopers. You get in the set 2 regular and 2 airborne troopers of the 212th attack battalion. I'
column2: ll start with the regular ones. They feature the same helmet mold&nbsp
column3: as we saw in the Umbara wave in 2013. I have to say Lego did a pretty good job on the helmet mold.&nbsp
column4: They are a little tall ad lack holes in the side for attachments, but the rest is fine. These particular troopers feature the distinctive 212th orange triangle decoration along with scuff marks here and there, which is a very nice inclusion. The head is the same seen on the ep2 clones Lego has released. I would just like to throw&nbsp
column5: out that any clone trooper that has this head is from ep2 or ep3, not the Clone Wars TV show. I noticed Brickset listed the Battle of Saleucami under The Clone Wars, but it&nbsp
column6: should be under Episode III. Anyway, moving on. The torso features nice printing, continuing the orange triangle and scuff pattern. The arms, unfortunately, don&#39
column7: t sport any printing which is one of&nbsp
column8: the major downsides to the set. He has black hands like all the other clones Lego has produced. Onto his legs. The legs continue the 212th pattern. It&#39
column9: s nice to finally see Lego starting to make leg printing a priority for not only clones but for most figures in the Star Wars universe. Unfortunately, the printing ends halfway down the legs, only half completing the knee pads. On to the airborne trooper. The helmet mold is exclusive&nbsp
column10: to this figure and is of the same quality as the other helmet. The printing on the helmet is exceptional and features the airborne troopers&#39
column11: distinct two slanted orange stripes, also featured on the torso and left leg. The torso sports a few slings either holding ammo or attached&nbsp
column12: to armor. Scuff marks are also present on the torso, along with the&nbsp
column13: helmet and legs as well. The troop has one orange arm am one white arm, the orange arm representing a large orange shoulder pad on the right side. Lego was generous enough to include a light bluish grey kama, which shows attention to detail. The legs are similar to the other trooper, but include airborne trooper marks. Sorry this has been such a long section, but the figures are the most&nbsp

column1: The build is not very interesting. The actual Octupara droid itself is pretty repetitive with building three of the same legs. Building 4 (12 in my case) figures are also pretty tedious.
The completed model is pretty dull. I do not recommend
column2: using it in MOCs, as it is pretty inaccurate. There&#39
column3: s really not much to say about it. If you&#39
column4: re a part collector,&nbsp
column5: the best thing to do would be to scrap it down for parts. I broke two of the Octupara&nbsp
column6: droids and built a more accurate one out of them, and I was pleased with how it turned out.

column1: Obviously, you will want to get this set for the figures, not the
column2: model. This specific selection of figures makes it one if the best army builders in a while. The thing that would make this set perfect would be the inclusion of a crab droid instead of an Octupara droid. This motivated me to go&nbsp
column3: onto Bricklink and order a few parts to make my own, which turned out pretty good. Overall, this is a great battle pack for anyone into clone troopers or into collecting minifigures. It also offers an alternative&nbsp
column4: to buying custom 212th attack battalion troopers online. Basically: it&#39

,TRUE,5,4,2,4,5 Jon_Brick","2014-06-07T22:58:06.487Z","A throughly enjoyable set.","

Battle-packs have been around for a while now, almost eight years in fact and in those eight years some things have remained largely the same such as the piece count (averaging at about 83 pieces) and the number of figures included (only
column2: 7654:&nbsp
column3: Droids Battle Pack&nbsp
column4: and&nbsp
column5: 8015:&nbsp
column8: t have exactly four minifigures instead having seven and five minifigures respectively), while on the other hand some&nbsp
column9: things have changed such as improved design of the minifigures and the set overall, as well as a rise in price. Another thing that has changed with the battle-packs over time is the division of figures based which side they&#39
column10: re on, for a while two sets were released each year both based on a certain peroid of time in the Star Wars universe but each focusing on one side of the opposing armies, then in 2012 the battle-packs merged sides (for example having either Clones vs. Droids or Rebels vs. The Empire in each set) and each set was based on a different time peroid and now in 2014 things have changed yet again by having battle-packs based around different points in the Star Wars timeline and by having some only contain clones or imperials while another has clones and a droid.Hopefully though the thing that will always remain the same about battle-packs is the quality since, for the most part, they have all been pretty good buy and even the worst one *cough* 8015: Assassin Droids Battle Pack *cough* being at least worth considering.&nbsp

column1: As is the case with most battle-packs there really isn'
column2: t much to the set besides the minifigures (which are superb but more on that in a bit), usually a little ship or speeder is provided for the figures to use which is fine but&nbsp
column4: Utapau Troopers&nbsp
column5: stands out as being even better than usual. At first I wasn&#39
column6: t sure why this battle pack in particular caught my interest the clones are nice but not any more detailed than most of the other Star Wars figures released recently but then it struck me, by having four minifigures versus a large enemy this battle-pack has done something that no other has and has ended being one of the best battle-packs released so far.&nbsp

column6: t look nearly as stylish or accurate as the previous blasters (even the old megaphone blasters almost look better) they make up for in functionality and these blasters are actually rather powerful given their size as they are able to knock a minifigure over and back quite a bit.

column1: The four minifigures included are two Clone Paratroopers and two 212 Clone Troopers. Even for licensed minifigures based on characters from a live-action film
column2: these minifigures are detailed with a truly incredible attention to detail&nbsp
column3: with pouches and scuff marks to add to the battle hardened trooper look.&nbsp

column2: height: 457px
column3: />

column2: s helmet is very nice and much rounder than that of the standard clone trooper, resembling an upside down bucket with a oversized lip. The helmet has a black long, thin visor going across the middle with two slanted orange lines coming out the upper side, a small black mark below to show the nose ridge and scuff marks above and below the visor. The helmet breather is vertical down the middle half with orange marks on each side of it at the bottom and two vents on the left and right sides of the bottom. The front torso is printed with the standard clone trooper armour overlaid with various details and orange highlights on the belt pouches. The upper left side of the troopers chestplate is just printed with two downward-slanted orange lines while the right side of the chestplate has a black, with orange highlight, shoulder/chest-pad of some sort with two light grey straps going down from it to the two main pouches on the belt at the bottom. A medium tan ammo strap also goes down from the top right to the bottom left. The trooper&#39
column3: s left arm is plain white while the right arm is orange. The legs are white but have some very nice printing to show the armour ridges and kneeplate with the left kneeplate being orange with two slanted orange lines above it.

column2: height: 423px

column1: The back of the helmet is plain white but is mould with two vertical ridges going down the center and starting from the middle. The back torso also has the standard clone printing but with a continuation of the tan ammo strap and a light grey strap going up to the little bit of shoulder pad on the trooper'
column2: s right. The back of the legs have no printing but are covered by a clone armour skirt seen previously in another battle-pack (9488) but this time coloured in medium stone-grey.
height: 470px

column1: Most battle-packs are made to be paired with other sets or battle-packs for opposings sides but as mentioned before this battle-pack is especially good because it includes mutiple minifigures from the same army but also provided an enemy for them to fight. But another thing that
column3: Utapau Troopers&nbsp

column2: m saying is that this set is a great example of the variety that has been missing from the battle-packs but that also seems to recently be absent from the Star Wars theme as a whole. This set reminds me of when I was a child and I only had a small amount of my own money (something I&#39
column3: m sure many others remember), aside from Christmas&#39

,TRUE,5,5,4,4,4 jackybrick","2014-05-19T20:47:32.29Z","Shoot that Tri-droid, men!!! (- because now you really can)","

I was really excited, when LEGO started producing these new, really-shooting minifig blasters, so far- mainly for the Star Wars sets. I was also a bit indecisive, whether to pick this battle pack (75036) or the Death Star Troopers (75034), because both of them include interesting minifigures. Finally, I decided to get this one first, chiefly because it has more of the new blasters (4) than the other one (2).
The set comes in a small (although larger than the 2013 battle packs tiny ones), rectangular-shaped box. On the front boxart you can see a simple battle scene, where the Utapau
column2: Troopers are firing at the Tri-droid. Except the usual set info (age, set number, set name,...) there&#39
column3: s also a notice about the new blasters included. The back side of the box shows some more battle scenes, as well as the set features.

column1: So, in the box are hiding two unnumbered bags of parts and a little instruction booklet. The instructions are accurate and will guide you quickly and easily through the build. At the end of the instructions, the features of the set are shown again and except that, (and the parts inventory of course), there'
column2: s only one advert- for the LEGO SW website, so not any 2014 SW wave 1 adverts or a minifig-list, as you would maybe expect.
font-size: 20px
column3: letter-spacing: -0.75px
column4: >Parts

column1: New weapons, as well as the new, exclusive helmet moulds for the Airborne Clone Troopers are included. You also get two of the rare skirts/lower capes, which are carefully packaged in the little, white, cardboard wrapping, inside one of the bags. The dome mould, used
column2: as the top of the Tri-droid, is also new colour. You get some extra pieces as always, e.g. the trans-blue studs, or a trigger used in the blasters,...

column1: No stickers are used for this set.
One of the main factors of this little set- you get two of each- Airborne and 212th
column2: Battalion Troopers. Personally, I like the Airborne guys more. All of the Troopers have a one-side-printed faces with the same, rather angry expression, nice double-sided torso printing and the legs printing as well. And there&#39
column3: s yet one another thing worth the notice, and that is, that the Airborne Troopers torso-pieces have a different colour&nbsp
column4: for each of their arm (left one=white, right one=orange)- that&#39
column5: s pretty cool, I think.&nbsp

column1: The build is mostly simple,nothing challenging, maybe except for the part, where you have to put the skirts on your minifig'
column2: s legs properly. In the case of the Tri-droid, the more interesting part is building it&#39
column3: s base, &#39
column4: cause&#39
column5: the legs are rather repetitive.

column2: ll take you only 10-15 minutes and everything will be complete.

column1: The fact, that you get something new (in the case of battle packs), and not just another speeder or a small cannon, makes you feeling satisfied about this set and the blaster shooting mechanism works really well, and it really is boosting the play experience to a high-level.

I can only recommend this battle pack to anyone, who likes to play with their sets even sometimes, not only has them displayed somewhere. Even if, you are not a huge SW fan, but you like the space themed sets, get it for the new blasters, some nice figs and an interesting droid-battle-machine. And of course, this set works well as an army builder, because you won'
column2: t get tired of these cool&nbsp
column3: minifigs so easliy. &nbsp
column4: &nbsp

,TRUE,5,5,4,5,4 PooPotato","2014-04-03T22:54:34.53Z","Airborne to the Rescue!","

*I would like to note that legomuffin413 is absolutely correct about the Tri-Droid appearing in miniature form in the Battle of Utapau.
column2: Everything I say about this droid not appearing in the films is incorrect, but I still stand by my opinion that a crab-droid would have worked much better.*

column1: The Battle of Utapau was one of the most exciting scenes in Star Wars Episode III, even if it only lasted for 10 minutes.
column2: Star Wars Battlefront II expanded on the battle, creating a wonderful battleground with movie accurate details, and furthered my interest in the troops of the 212th Attack Battalion led by Commander Cody.

column1: The box was the same style as the other 2 battlepacks released in this line, as were the instructions.
The parts included with the main model in this battlepack could be incredibly useful for a MOC, especially the dark tan dome on top of the Octuptarra magna tri-droid.
column2: The amount of pieces included is quite disappointing however, standing at a weak 86. &nbsp
column3: This in no way justifies the $13 price tag, especially when 75000 Clone Troopers vs. Droidekas has 124.

column1: The minifigs are the star of the set, so naturally I will discuss more about them.

column2: 212th Attack Batallion&nbsp
column3: troopers, who look very accurate when compared to their film counterparts. &nbsp
column4: The new helmet design and the orange highlights make this trooper look way better than the previous design in 75013. &nbsp
column5: A platoon of these guys disembarking a Republic Gunship would look great in any MOC as well. &nbsp

column2: to me were the 2nd Airborne Clone Troopers. &nbsp
column3: A little known fact is that these guys are not part of the 212th Attack Battalion, but coexist with them under the 7th&nbsp
column4: Sky Corps. &nbsp
column5: The troopers come with the new cloth &#39
column7: , and have the same ugly new blasters that come with the other battlepacks. The torso/leg printing is outstanding, and the new helmet design is too good to stay exclusive to this set. &nbsp
column8: Hopefully Lego makes more Episode III sets in the future.&nbsp

column2: t have any particularly exciting moments. &nbsp

column1: When compared to the source material, this model looks absolutely terrible.
column2: Considering that the tri-droid is a very large vehicle, the choice to include it as a battlepack&nbsp
column3: model was a poor one. &nbsp
column4: It should also be mentioned that a crab-droid would have worked wonderfully here, as you actually see them in the Battle of Utapau. &nbsp

column1: The minifigures in this set, like in Kashyyyk Troopers look wonderful, and it is very nice that you get 4 of them.
column2: However, the main model looks horrendous, and would have a much better future as scrap parts. &nbsp
column3: The minifigures are the only thing that are stopping this set from receiving a much lower mark.

column2: Kama&#39
column3: leg capes

column1: Amount of pieces is too small to justify the price

,TRUE,4,5,3,5,3 Odeinoichus","2017-01-04T18:29:43.993Z","Lackluster Battle Pack compared to other offerings","

Set #75036 Utapau Troopers: Lately LEGO has been giving us way more battle packs than they used to. Some of them are nicely thought out and designed. Others are just so, so, and this one is a bit of a mixed bag honestly. Read on to find out why.
The designs of 2014 once again take their cues from Hasbro&rsquo
column2: s packaging design, with Darth Vader in the top left corner and the dark blueish coloring with the strange cracks of red shown. This packaging is very similar to Hasbro&rsquo
column3: s Saga Legends line, it isn&rsquo
column4: t as collector oriented as the Black Series, however the shared design once again must be a Disney mandated thing. Since I doubt Hasbro or LEGO enjoy having their products in identical looking packaging. I wonder if the licensor makes the designs for the product packaging and passes it on to all of the licensees who are working with their franchise.

column1: The instructions are the same as past Star Wars sets, with cross-promotional imagery being very minimal for this 18 page manual. Honestly this set&rsquo
column2: s instructions do what they set out to do, show you how to build the contents. However I think they do suffer having less pages, for this set though I can see why they might be a bit minimalistic compared to larger more piece heavy sets.

column1: Considering the limited number of pieces in this set, nothing really stands out. New blasters are introduced in 2014 and you can get some nice new leg pauldrons for the Airborne Troopers in this set, as far as the main model is concerned. Nothing much to say here.
You receive four very impressive looking minifigures in this set, which is a big draw for the set if you&rsquo
column2: re a fan of clones. In particular you will get two each of the Airborne Clone Trooper and the 212th Battalion Trooper.

column1: 212th Battalion Trooper: Both of these minifigures have the exact same print, they are based on the Phase 2 clones with the more rounded helmets, which are closer to the Stormtrooper design. Both of them come with the new stud launcher blaster, not the molded blasters that past sets have favored. This is a new play feature which is hit or miss honestly, as an AFOL the weapons are a bit unfortunate for when you want to display these Clones amongst the army of others you have with the sculpted blaster pieces.
As a kid however you might enjoy this accessory more, although you&rsquo
column2: re bound to lose a tone of studs. Each set includes six extra studs for launching, and you&rsquo
column3: ll no doubt have tons of the clear blue studs if you collect LEGO regularly, as they are often given out as spare pieces since they are easily lost or misplaced.

column1: The print details on the 212th Troopers are pretty sweet, some of the most detailed clones I&rsquo
column2: ve gotten. LEGO seems to be stepping up their game lately, with all the awesome detail work found in such Themes as Legends of Chima and The LEGO Movie, introducing more fine details and movie accuracy prints is a really big step up from the LEGO I had growing up.

column1: Airborne Clone Troopers: These minifigs have even more great detail, with double-sided torso printing, leg printing, helmet printing and the standard Clone Heads found in most sets. This minifigure is interesting because he has one orange arm and one white arm. Again there are two stud launchers for accessories instead of the sculpted blasters we&rsquo
column2: ve become accustomed to.

column1: I suppose that means you can consider these weapons as heavy blasters or something. Or just bricklink spare regular blasters for your army of clones. Overall though this set is a prime example of why LEGO minifigures are the go-to collectibles in these sets.

This is a very poor build, since the model is very small and not as fun as past battle packs. Honestly while you got vehicles in the past, here you get to build a Tri-Droid model which is very fast to build, not to tricky and lacks some substance. It&rsquo
column2: s a solid build, don&rsquo
column3: t get me wrong, however I feel that this is borderline a box full of five minifigures because of the fact you&rsquo
column4: re building a character instead of a vehicle.

column1: I love the quirky nature of the Tri-Droid, the LEGO model captures this nicely with the awkward almost 50&rsquo
column2: s era sci-fi looking attack droid element. What I don&rsquo
column3: t like is that this model has three flick-fire missiles situated around the upper dome, this play feature makes the model look goofy and the missiles stick out, what would have helped it more would have been to incorporate the stud launching gimmick of the blasters, that way you wouldn&rsquo
column4: t have three missiles sticking out where the guns would be located on the on-screen model.

column2: m not a fan of the colour scheme, when Hasbro made this particular droid they used a much darker, black colour scheme for their figure. I think black would have made for a better looking droid, it would have been less awkward, especially if they chose a different colour for the upper dome and stuff.

column1: Overall this is a pretty weak offering from LEGO, considering the number of pieces in other battle packs I think they could have done better here, maybe throw in enough parts for two Tri-Droids at least, making the set more viable for army building since you&rsquo
column2: d get two Tri-Droids with four Utapau clones each time. Mildly recommended as an army builder, however I strongly suggest you try to get it on sale.

column1:
,TRUE,3,2,2,3,3
123MrBrick","2016-11-28T00:03:00.81Z","One of the Best Army Builders In a Long Time","<div class=""description"">
Star Wars battle packs have a history of being incredibly popular and useful for building armies. This one is certainly no exception, and is one of the best examples of all time.
The set comes in a small thumb punch box. The front shows the set in a basic action shot and the back shows off the new (at the time) guns, as well as some other features. Standard fare.
Obviously the main draw of this set is the minifig parts, but the new guns are pretty neat. The dark tan parts on the tridroid are useful as well.

Now this is why you bought the set! Here we have the long awaited 212th clones, and the 212th airborne troopers. They all share the same boring new clone face, but they are all perfectly detailed. The prints contain the right mix of scuffs, dirt, and rank markings to make a set of very realistic minifigs. The airborne helmet sculpt in particular is superb, as well as the soft cloth kamas at their waists.
Quick and easy build for this one. Similar to building a small clone walker, followed by a cylinder portion. It took me probably around 7 or 8 minutes.

The tridroid is nothing to write home about. It is a decent looking thing, not bad by any means, but it could use some eyes or other details. It feels like a parody of a larger model we have yet to see. However, in the official story there are various sizes of this droid unit, so it scales well with the clones and other Separatist vehicles.

column2: ll really buy this set for and they are perfect representations of the 212th troopers from Revenge of the Sith. The tridroid is a fun little model too and is a nice bonus. This is a good model for other battle packs: 4 troops from one side and a vehicle/droid/base from the other is a good balance and prevents the necessity of a second battle pack. Recommended for Star Wars and minifig fans.
